attributes.action: address "Yentl" gender disparities in angina care
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
AOL today reports that,

"Women are likely to receive a lower level of medical care for the common heart condition angina than men, scientists have revealed.

Researchers identified a "gender-based pecking order" in the treatment of the illness - and claimed women came lower down the list than their male counterparts.

Given that 1.2 million people in the UK are estimated to suffer from angina, and it is more common in men. But many women are also sufferers and scientists at the University of Aberdeen, who carried out the research, said the lower levels of treatment for women were "worse than we anticipated".

They did not put the findings down to simple sexism, however, and said "broader cultural factors" were at play.

These include the fact that men are more likely to display classic symptoms, such as chest pain, and that men are more likely to be encouraged to visit the doctor than women.

The researchers called for a campaign highlighting the problem among women to be launched.
